abstract.text: Apply adhoc styles via a delegate.
This supports a workflow where a style requires
computation that can only occur in the scope of
the specific object being styled – for example,
if a color is derived from data held by that object,
where said data is not available to the theme.
The delegate may style itself or some sibling/child
or related object as needed, for example by querying.
Use this in conjuction with style attributes “styleFromDelegate”
for decorative styles and “typographicStyleFromDelegate”
for typographical styles, the only difference being the
order in which the styles are applied, with the former
(styleFromDelegate) being applied in the decorative style
group and the latter (typographicStyleFromDelegate)
in typographical style group
(and before decorative styles) are applied.
Otherwise, cascade rules (creational/normal/state)
apply as normal.
NOTE: It’s also possible to integrate with style
delegates by calling “applyStyle()” directly from
the delegate itself, rather than via the style
attributes mentioned. This is useful in case the
entire style for the object is handled in the
the delegate “applyStyle()” method (it’s obviously
more efficient since there is no theme resolution).
If taking this approach, be sure to conform to
this protocol via extension and keep that conformance
in the same file as the overall theme for organizational
reasons.

Apply style to this delegate with some contextual
information, for example via a nested Enum on this
object with associated values.
